content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Angel Rodriguez: I was born in Los Angeles, and I've spent my whole life here, which feels both comforting and limiting at times. Growing up in the Pacific area, I remember the sounds of the ocean and the smell of the salt in the air. My parents worked hard, but we never had much money. My dad worked at a factory, and my mom cleaned houses. They both only finished high school, but they always encouraged me to do better. I was the first in my family to graduate from high school, which felt like a huge accomplishment. I'm currently in school, trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. I speak Spanish at home, and I've always felt connected to my Mexican roots, even though I was born in the U.S. I'm Catholic, and my faith has been a big part of my life, especially growing up in a close-knit family. I've never been married, and I've never served in the military, but I've always been focused on my education and making something of myself. I know I don't have a lot of money, but I'm determined to work my way up.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Angel Rodriguez: There was a moment during my junior year of high school when I realized I had a choice—stay in the same cycle as my parents or try to break free. I had always been good in school, but I never really thought about what I wanted to do with my life. One day, my teacher, Mrs. Alvarez, noticed I was quiet during a discussion about college opportunities. She pulled me aside and asked me if I had ever considered going to college. I had never even thought about it, not because I didn't want to, but because I didn't know how. She offered to help me apply for scholarships and even connected me with a mentor who had grown up in the same neighborhood. That was the turning point. I started applying to colleges, and I got into a community college with a scholarship. It was the first time I felt like I had a real chance to change my future. I remember telling my parents that night, and they were so proud, even though they didn't fully understand what I was saying. That moment shaped who I am today—it made me realize that I had the power to choose a different path, even if it wasn't easy.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Angel Rodriguez: I think it was a conscious choice, but it felt like it just happened because I didn't realize how much I was capable of until that moment. I had always been told I could do better, but I never saw a clear path. Mrs. Alvarez gave me that path, and I chose to take it. It wasn't just about going to college—it was about proving to myself and my family that I could break the cycle. I remember sitting at the kitchen table that night, looking at the scholarship letter, and feeling this mix of fear and excitement. I knew it wouldn't be easy, but I also knew I didn't want to live the same life as my parents. That choice was mine, and I made it with my heart, even if I wasn't sure where it would lead.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Angel Rodriguez: Absolutely. I think if it weren't for Mrs. Alvarez and that mentor, I might have stayed in the same place, just going through the motions. But there were others too—like the community center in our neighborhood that offered free tutoring and college prep workshops. I didn't go at first because I felt embarrassed about needing help, but once I did, it opened up a whole world I didn't know existed. And then there were the scholarships themselves—organizations that didn't just give money but also support, like counseling and mentorship programs. I think it takes a village, you know? People who believe in you even when you don't believe in yourself. I'm still grateful for every hand that reached out to me because without them, I don't think I would have had the courage to take that first step.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Angel Rodriguez: Right now, I don't have a partner or children. My family is my parents and my younger sister, Maria. She's 16 and in high school, and she's already showing a lot of promise. I try to be a good example for her, even though I'm still figuring things out myself. My parents are proud of me, but they still worry about me because they've never seen anyone in our family go to college. I make sure to call them every week, and we talk about everything—school, my future, even the struggles I face with money. I know they want the best for me, but they also want me to be safe and not take too many risks. It's a balance, but I think they're starting to understand that I'm not just chasing a dream—I'm building a better life for all of us.

Going through those interview questions felt like looking back at the journey that shaped me, from my childhood in Los Angeles to the moment I decided to break free from the cycle my parents were in. It was humbling to reflect on how much my family, teachers, and community supported me when I didn't even know I needed help. I realized how much of who I am today comes from that turning point in high school, when Mrs. Alvarez gave me the push I needed to believe in a future beyond my current circumstances. Talking about my family, especially my sister, reminded me of the responsibility I feel to be a role model and show her that dreams are possible, even if the path isn't clear at first. I'm still figuring things out, but I know I'm on the right track because I made the choice to change my life—and I'm not going back now.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Angel Rodriguez: My grandparents live in Guadalajara, Mexico, and I haven't seen them in a few years because of the cost of traveling. My grandfather used to be a mechanic, and my grandmother was a teacher there before she moved to the U.S. to be closer to my parents. I have a close relationship with them, even though we don't talk as much as I'd like. My mom keeps in touch with them more often, and she translates for me when we speak on the phone. I feel a deep connection to my roots, especially when I hear my grandmother tell stories about her childhood in Mexico. I wish I could visit them more, but I know that one day I will. They've always believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself, and that means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Angel Rodriguez: I have a few close friends from high school who I still keep in touch with, even though we're all going different paths now. One of them, Luis, is working at a local restaurant, and he's thinking about going back to school for culinary arts. We used to hang out all the time, talking about our futures, and even though things are busy for both of us now, I still check in on him. He's been a big support system for me, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed with school and money. Then there's my roommate, Javier, who's also in community college. We've been through a lot together—late-night study sessions, figuring out how to budget, and even helping each other with applications. He's like a brother to me, and I know I can count on him. I think having people like Luis and Javier in my life has been just as important as the mentors and teachers. They remind me that I'm not alone in this journey, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Angel Rodriguez: I live in a neighborhood on the west side of Los Angeles, near the beach. It's a mix of old and new—some of the houses are decades old, with peeling paint and small yards, while others are newer apartments built for people like me who are trying to make it on their own. The streets can be loud at night, with music and cars, but there's also a sense of community here. There are small businesses, like the corner store where I buy my groceries, and a few local restaurants that serve great food. I walk to school most days, and I always pass by the same group of kids hanging out near the park. It's not the easiest place to live—rent is high, and sometimes it feels like everyone is just scraping by—but there's something about the energy here that keeps me going. I know I'm not alone in this struggle, and that gives me strength. Plus, being close to the ocean reminds me of where I came from and why I'm fighting so hard to get somewhere better.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Angel Rodriguez: I'd say I feel safe here, but it's not always easy. There are times when I walk home late at night and feel the eyes on me, especially when I'm carrying my books or heading to the bus stop. But I've learned to be aware of my surroundings, and I always stick to the main streets where there are more people around. The community here is tight-knit in its own way—people look out for each other, even if they don't know you personally. I've had neighbors who've offered me advice on school, or helped me out when I was short on rent. It's not perfect, but I think the sense of belonging here helps me feel safer than I would in a place where no one knows your name. I know I'm not rich, but I also know I'm not alone, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Angel Rodriguez: Living here has been a mix of challenges and small victories. On one hand, the cost of living is tough—rent eats up most of my paycheck, and I have to be careful with every dollar. I've had to take on part-time jobs to help out, like working at a local bookstore a few days a week. It's not much, but it helps. On the other hand, there's a kind of resilience here that I admire. I see people my age working hard, going to school, and still finding ways to make it work. It's not always easy, but there's a sense of hope that keeps me going. I also love being close to the beach—it's my escape, a place where I can think, breathe, and remember why I'm fighting for a better future. I know I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm learning every day, and that's something I can be proud of.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my support system has shaped who I am. Talking about my parents and sister reminded me of the responsibility I feel to be a role model, even as I'm still figuring things out. It also made me realize how much I owe to the people in my life—my parents, my sister, my friends, and even the neighbors who've helped me when I needed it most. My neighborhood might not be perfect, but it's home, and it's where I've learned to be resilient. I know I'm not alone in this journey, and that gives me strength to keep pushing forward.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Angel Rodriguez: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it's also full of little surprises. I usually wake up around 7 a.m., make a quick breakfast, and then head to class. My classes are in the morning, so I try to get there early to find a seat and get some work done before the day starts. After class, I often grab lunch with my roommate, Javier, or sometimes I just eat at the campus cafeteria. In the afternoons, I work part-time at the bookstore, which is actually pretty rewarding—I get to meet people and even recommend books to customers, which I enjoy. On some days, I have study sessions with friends or meet with my mentor from the community center. I also try to set aside time for myself, whether it's going for a walk by the beach or just sitting in my room and listening to music. Weekends are a bit different—I might help my parents out with chores or go visit my sister, Maria, to check in on her and see how she's doing in high school. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to prioritize and make the most of every moment.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Angel Rodriguez: I work part-time at a local bookstore, usually on weekends and sometimes during the afternoons when my classes are done. It's not a lot of hours, but it helps me cover some of my expenses and gives me a chance to interact with people outside of school. I enjoy talking to customers about books, even if I don't know much about every genre. It's also a good way to pass the time and keep my mind active. I've learned a lot from the people I work with—some of them are students like me, others are older and have been in the industry for years. They've shared stories about their lives, their struggles, and their dreams, which has inspired me to keep pushing forward. I know it's just a small job, but it's part of the journey, and I'm grateful for every opportunity I get.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Angel Rodriguez: Outside of work and school, I also have a routine of helping out at home whenever I can. My parents still rely on me for things like picking up groceries or helping with errands, especially since they both work long hours. I also try to set aside time each week to call my sister, Maria, and check in on her. She's going through a lot in high school—balancing school, friends, and her own dreams—and I want to be there for her, even if I'm still figuring things out myself. I also have this habit of writing in a journal whenever I feel overwhelmed. It's my way of processing everything, from the stress of school to the pressure of making ends meet. I know it might sound cliché, but I really do believe that every small step counts, and I'm trying to make the most of every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Angel Rodriguez: Lately, I've started waking up a little earlier to get in some extra study time before class. I realized that if I want to keep up with my courses and still work part-time, I need to be more efficient with my time. I've also been trying to eat healthier, which has been a challenge on a tight budget, but I've started buying more fruits and vegetables from the local farmers' market on weekends. I've even joined a study group at the community center, which has been really helpful. It's amazing how much you can learn from others when you're not alone in the struggle. I'm also thinking about applying for more scholarships and grants, so I've been researching online and talking to my mentor about the best ways to do that. It's a lot to take in, but I'm trying to stay focused and not let the pressure get to me. Every small change I make feels like a step toward something bigger, and that gives me hope.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Angel Rodriguez: I don't have children yet, but I think about what it would be like if I did. If I had kids, I'd want them to have opportunities I never had—like access to good education, a safe neighborhood, and the support of a community that believes in them. I imagine their days would start early, maybe with a breakfast of toast and fruit, then heading off to school. After school, they'd probably have some kind of activity—sports, music, or maybe even a club that helps them explore their interests. I'd want them to feel supported, not just by me, but by teachers, friends, and mentors who can guide them. I know it's a lot to think about, but I'm already trying to be the kind of person who would make that possible for them.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my support system has shaped who I am. Talking about my parents and sister reminded me of the responsibility I feel to be a role model, even as I'm still figuring things out. It also made me realize how much I owe to the people in my life—my parents, my sister, my friends, and even the neighbors who've helped me when I needed it most. My neighborhood might not be perfect, but it's home, and it's where I've learned to be resilient. I know I'm not alone in this journey, and that gives me strength to keep pushing forward.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Angel Rodriguez: My health has been pretty good overall, though I've had my share of stress-related issues. I used to get really bad headaches from studying too much or worrying about money, but I've started taking better care of myself. I've been going to the campus health center for check-ups, and they gave me some tips on managing stress—like deep breathing exercises and getting enough sleep. I also try to exercise when I can, usually by walking along the beach or doing some stretches in my room. It's not much, but it helps me feel more grounded. I've learned that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my mind, especially when everything else feels so uncertain. I'm not perfect at it, but I'm trying to make it a priority because I know my health is the foundation for everything else in my life.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Angel Rodriguez: Staying healthy is both easier and harder than it sounds. On one hand, I have a routine now—like walking by the beach or doing a few stretches in the morning—that helps me feel more balanced. I also try to eat better, even if it means buying cheaper fruits or making meals last longer. But on the other hand, money is always tight, and sometimes I skip meals or don't have time to rest because I'm juggling school, work, and helping out at home. The stress of it all can take a toll, and I've had days where I just feel drained. What makes it easier is knowing that even small things—like a walk or a few deep breaths—can make a difference. What makes it hard is feeling like I don't have enough time or resources to take care of myself the way I want to. But I'm learning, and I hope that one day I can be healthier—not just for myself, but for my family too.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Angel Rodriguez: In the past two years, I actually had a pretty serious experience with my health that I haven't talked about much. A few months ago, I started having chest pains and shortness of breath after I was working late at the bookstore and studying for exams. At first, I thought it was just stress, but my roommate, Javier, insisted I go to the campus health center. The doctor ran some tests and found that I had a mild case of asthma, which I didn't even know I had. It was a bit of a shock, but it also made me realize how much I was pushing myself without taking care of my body. Since then, I've been using an inhaler when needed and trying to manage my stress better. It's been a learning experience, and I'm grateful I didn't ignore the symptoms. I know I can't control everything in my life, but I can control how I take care of myself, and that's something I'm committed to now.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Angel Rodriguez: Honestly, it's been a challenge, but I've learned to adapt. At first, I was worried that the asthma would make it harder to keep up with school and work, especially since I'm always on the go. But once I started managing it with the inhaler and making sure I take breaks when I need to, it became easier. I still push myself, but now I know when to slow down and listen to my body. It's funny, because before this, I never thought about my health at all—I was too focused on just getting by. Now, I see it as another part of the journey, something I have to take care of if I want to keep moving forward. I know it's not perfect, but I'm trying to be more mindful, and that's something I can be proud of.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Angel Rodriguez: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—hope, frustration, and a lot of growth. There were moments when I felt like I was making progress, like when I got accepted into a transfer program at a four-year university, which felt like a huge step forward. But there were also times when I felt overwhelmed, especially when I had to juggle more responsibilities at work and school. I remember one particular month when I was working late shifts at the bookstore, struggling with a heavy course load, and also helping my parents with some unexpected bills. I felt like I was running on empty, but I didn't want to give up. What kept me going was knowing that I was doing this for my sister, for my family, and for the future I want to build. I've also learned to ask for help more often, whether it's from my roommate, my mentor, or even my parents. I used to think I had to do everything on my own, but I've come to realize that it's okay to lean on others. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and celebrate the small wins, like getting an A on a test or finally saving up for a new pair of shoes. I know I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm learning to trust the process and believe that every step, no matter how small, is still a step forward.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes and health made me realize how much I've grown in the past year. I used to think that making small changes, like waking up earlier or eating healthier, wasn't going to make a difference, but now I see how those little steps add up. It's also been eye-opening to talk about my health—especially my asthma diagnosis. I never thought about my body's limits before, but now I understand that taking care of myself isn't just about being healthy, it's about being strong enough to keep fighting for my future. I've learned that I don't have to do everything alone, and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm proud of how far I've come, and I know I'm on the right path.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Angel Rodriguez: I've definitely had moments where I felt really down, especially when things felt too heavy to handle. There were times when I'd sit in my room for hours, just staring at the ceiling, wondering if I was doing enough or if I'd ever get out of this cycle. I used to push those feelings aside, thinking I couldn't afford to feel weak or vulnerable. But over the past year, I've started to recognize that feeling anxious or even a little depressed isn't a sign of failure—it's just part of the process. I've been talking to my mentor more about it, and she's helped me understand that it's okay to not have all the answers. I've also started seeing a counselor at the community center, which has been really helpful. It's not always easy opening up, but I've learned that taking care of my mental health is just as important as taking care of my body. I still have days where I feel like I'm barely holding on, but I'm trying to be more honest with myself and not ignore the signs anymore. I know I'm not alone in this, and that gives me strength to keep going.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Angel Rodriguez: For my family, it's been a mix of pride and worry. My parents are so proud of me for getting into that transfer program, but they also worry because they've never seen anyone in our family go to a four-year university before. They want me to succeed, but they also want me to be safe and not take too many risks. My mom has been especially supportive, even though she doesn't always understand the details of what I'm doing. She keeps asking me, 'Are you sure this is the right path?' and I have to remind her that I've worked hard to get here. My sister, Maria, has been my biggest cheerleader—she texts me every day to check in and tells me she's going to be the first in our family to go to college too. It's amazing how much she's grown, and I feel like I'm not just fighting for myself anymore, but for all of us. I know they're scared, but I also know they believe in me, and that gives me the strength to keep going, even when things get tough.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Angel Rodriguez: For me, religion has always been a source of strength, especially growing up in a close-knit family where faith was a central part of our lives. My parents and grandparents always made sure we went to church on Sundays, and I remember sitting in the back of the pew, listening to the priest talk about God's love and the importance of family. Even though I'm not always sure I understand everything the priest says, I find comfort in the rituals—like saying the rosary with my mom or lighting a candle for my sister before exams. It's not just about believing in God for me; it's about having that sense of hope and connection to something bigger than myself. When things get tough, like when I'm struggling with school or money, I find myself turning to prayer or going to Mass, not because I think it will fix everything, but because it reminds me that I'm not alone. I know some people might see religion as something outdated or restrictive, but for me, it's been a way to stay grounded and keep moving forward, even when the path isn't clear.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Angel Rodriguez: I don't use social media too much, honestly. I know a lot of people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through Instagram or Facebook, but I find it more distracting than helpful for me. I do have a Facebook account because my parents use it to stay in touch with family and friends back in Mexico, and I like being able to see photos of my grandparents or check in with my cousins. I also follow a few pages that post motivational quotes or stories about people from similar backgrounds, which sometimes gives me a boost when I'm feeling down. But I try not to get caught up in comparing my life to others' highlight reels. I've seen how social media can make people feel good or bad about themselves, and I don't want that to affect me. Instead, I prefer to stay connected through real conversations—whether it's talking to my roommate, my sister, or even my parents on the phone. I think there's a place for social media, but for me, it's not the main way I stay connected to the world.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Angel Rodriguez: Honestly, I don't rely on social media for support the way some people do. I know it can be a source of connection, but I've seen how it can also bring more stress than comfort. When I'm going through a tough time, I find that talking to someone in person or on the phone feels more real. My roommate, my sister, or even my parents—they're the ones who really understand what I'm going through. I've tried using Facebook to reach out to old friends or see what others are doing, but it never feels like the same kind of support. I think I'd rather keep things simple, like calling someone when I need to talk instead of scrolling through someone else's life. I know it's not the most modern way, but it works for me.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent experiences made me realize how much I've grown in the past year. I used to push through everything without really taking care of myself, thinking that if I just worked harder, I could make it through. But after being diagnosed with asthma and learning to manage it, I've come to understand that my health is just as important as my education or my work. It's not about being perfect—it's about being mindful and knowing when to slow down and listen to my body. I've also learned that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, to feel anxious, or even depressed sometimes. What matters is that I don't ignore those feelings and that I reach out for help when I need it. Talking to my mentor, seeing a counselor, and even just having conversations with my family and friends have made a huge difference. I used to think I had to do everything on my own, but now I know that asking for support is a sign of strength, not weakness. I'm still learning, and I know there's more to discover, but I'm proud of how far I've come and how much I've grown.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Angel Rodriguez: Lately, I've noticed that my stress levels have gone up a bit, especially with the added pressure of applying to transfer programs and trying to keep up with my part-time job. I used to think I could handle everything on my own, but I've started to realize that I need to take better care of my mental health. I've been trying new coping strategies, like journaling more often and even practicing mindfulness exercises I found online. I also started talking to my counselor more regularly, which has helped me process my feelings instead of bottling them up. It's not always easy—there are still days when I feel overwhelmed and like I'm not making progress fast enough—but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to celebrate the small victories. I've also started setting aside time each evening to just sit quietly and breathe, even if it's only for a few minutes. It's not a perfect solution, but it's something that helps me feel more grounded when everything else feels so uncertain.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Angel Rodriguez: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent eats up about half of my paycheck, and it's always tight because I'm still in school and not making a lot of money. I live in a small apartment with my roommate, Javier, and we split the cost, but even then, it's a struggle sometimes. Groceries are another big one—especially since I've been trying to eat healthier, which means buying more fresh produce and less processed food. I go to the local farmers' market on weekends when I can afford it, but sometimes I have to buy in bulk or look for sales to stretch my budget. Transportation is also a hit because I need to get to school, work, and sometimes help my parents out with errands. I use the bus most of the time, but when I'm running late or it's raining, I have to take a taxi or Uber, which can be expensive. My parents still help out when they can, but they're not making a lot either. It's a constant balancing act, trying to cover everything without going into debt. I've started tracking my expenses more carefully, and I'm trying to save even small amounts each month in case of emergencies. It's not easy, but I know I have to be responsible if I want to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Angel Rodriguez: Our household usually spends around $1,200 to $1,300 a month, depending on how much we have to spend on unexpected things like car repairs or medical bills. Rent is the biggest chunk—about $600 a month, which is a lot when you're splitting it with a roommate. Groceries come next, maybe around $300, and that's after I've started buying more fresh food and trying to eat better. Transportation is another $150 to $200, mostly for bus passes and the occasional taxi ride when I'm in a rush. Then there's the little stuff—phone bills, utilities, and personal expenses like toiletries or a new pair of shoes. We don't have a lot of extra money, so we have to be really careful with every dollar. Some months are better than others, but I've learned to track everything in a notebook so I can see where the money is going. It's not always easy, but I know that every little bit I save helps me get closer to my goals.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Angel Rodriguez: We rent our home, actually. It's a small apartment in a building that's been around for a while. The landlord is pretty strict about the rules, but I guess that's fair considering how tight the rent is. We're lucky to have a place to live, even if it's not much. My parents still live in the same house we grew up in, but they've been thinking about moving somewhere cheaper, maybe even a different part of the city. It's hard for them to leave because of the memories and the community they've built over the years, but they know they can't afford to stay forever. I help them out when I can, like paying for some of their bills or helping them look for places to rent. It's a lot to think about, but I know we're all just trying to make the best of what we have.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Angel Rodriguez: Over the past year, my bills have definitely gone up and down depending on the season and what was happening in our lives. In the summer, for example, we had to pay for air conditioning more than usual because it got really hot, and the electricity bill went up. Then, when school started again in the fall, I had to pay for more books and supplies, which added to the cost. We also had some unexpected expenses, like when my mom had to get her car fixed because the brakes were failing. That was a real hit to our budget, and we had to cut back on things like eating out or buying new clothes. Around the holidays, we tried to be more careful, but there were still costs for gifts and food. I remember one month when we had to skip a few meals just to cover the rent and utilities. It's been a lot to manage, but I've learned to be more flexible and find ways to save, like buying generic brands or using coupons when I can. It's not always easy, but I know we're all doing our best to make it work.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family's support means to me, even as I navigate my own struggles with stress, health, and emotional well-being. Talking about my parents' pride and worry reminded me that I'm not just fighting for myself, but for them too—especially my sister, Maria, who looks up to me and wants to follow in my footsteps. It also made me think about how I handle stress and emotional challenges. I used to believe I had to do everything on my own, but now I see how important it is to lean on others, whether it's my roommate, my mentor, or even my parents. I've also come to understand that my health is just as important as my education or my work, and that taking care of myself isn't a weakness—it's a necessity. I'm still learning, but I'm proud of how far I've come and how much I've grown in the process.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Angel Rodriguez: I don't have a traditional savings account, but I do save in small ways whenever I can. I keep a jar under my bed where I put spare change from work or any extra money I get from scholarships or part-time gigs. It's not much, maybe $20 or $30 a month, but it feels like something I can control. I also try to set aside a little bit of my paycheck each week, even if it's just $10 or $15, and put it toward something specific, like a new laptop I need for school or a trip to visit my grandparents in Mexico. I know it's not a lot, but it's a start. I used to think saving wasn't important when I was struggling to cover basic needs, but now I see it as another way to take charge of my future. Even if it's just a few dollars at a time, I believe that consistency matters, and I'm trying to build that habit, one small step at a time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Angel Rodriguez: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any big purchases, honestly. Life has taught me that unexpected things can happen—like when my mom had to fix her car or when I had to cover an unexpected medical bill for my asthma. I know I can't plan for everything, but I want to be prepared just in case. So, I try to set aside whatever I can, even if it's just a few dollars here and there. I also started thinking about saving for something bigger, like maybe a car one day, but that feels really far off right now. For now, I'm focused on building that emergency fund, even if it's just a little bit at a time. It's not much, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that I'm not completely caught off guard if something else comes up.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Angel Rodriguez: My occupation right now is a student, but I also work part-time at a local bookstore to help support myself and my family. At the bookstore, my main duties are helping customers find books, restocking shelves, and managing the checkout counter. I also get to organize events like book clubs or author readings, which I find really rewarding. The most important part of my job is interacting with people—learning their stories, recommending books that might interest them, and sometimes just having a conversation that makes their day a little better. It's not the kind of work that pays a lot, but it gives me a sense of purpose and helps me stay connected to the community. I've learned a lot from the people I work with, and I try to bring that same kind of care and attention to my studies. I see my work and education as two sides of the same coin—both are ways to build a better future for myself and for my family.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Angel Rodriguez: I usually work around 15 to 20 hours a week, depending on the semester and how much schoolwork I have. During busier times, like when I'm juggling exams or major projects, I might cut back to 15 hours so I can focus more on my studies. But when things are a little calmer, I'll work closer to 20 hours to try to save up more money. It's a tight balance, but I've learned to listen to my body and my schedule. If I work too much, I don't have enough time to rest or study, and that affects everything. So I try to stick to a routine—work on weekends and after classes during the week—so I can still make time for my family, my sister, and even my own well-being. It's not perfect, but it's the best I can do right now.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Angel Rodriguez: Actually, I only have one job right now—the bookstore. I tried to take on more work once, like doing some odd jobs around the neighborhood, but it got too overwhelming. I remember one time I was working at the bookstore, helping out at a local food bank on the weekends, and even doing some tutoring for younger kids in the community center. It was a lot, and I realized I couldn't keep up with everything. My body and mind were already stretched thin between school, work, and taking care of my family. I had to make a choice, and I decided to focus on the bookstore and my studies. It wasn't easy letting go of some of those other opportunities, but I knew I had to prioritize what was most important for my future. Now, I'm trying to be more efficient with the time I have, and I'm grateful for the job I have because it gives me a sense of stability and purpose.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much I've grown in managing my stress, understanding my financial situation, and recognizing the importance of emotional support. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me that I used to push through everything without really taking care of myself, thinking that if I just worked harder, I could make it through. But after being diagnosed with asthma and learning to manage it, I've come to understand that my mental and physical health are just as important as my education or my work. It's not about being perfect—it's about being mindful and knowing when to slow down and listen to my body. I've also learned that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, to feel anxious, or even depressed sometimes. What matters is that I don't ignore those feelings and that I reach out for help when I need it. Talking to my mentor, seeing a counselor, and even just having conversations with my family and friends have made a huge difference. I used to think I had to do everything on my own, but now I know that asking for support is a sign of strength, not weakness. I'm still learning, and I know there's more to discover, but I'm proud of how far I've come and how much I've grown.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Angel Rodriguez: In total, our household made around $1,800 in the past month, but that's after combining my part-time earnings, my parents' incomes, and any small financial help we get from family or community programs. My parents both work full-time—my dad at the factory and my mom as a cleaner—but their wages aren't enough to cover everything, especially with rent and utilities. I make about $600 a month from the bookstore, and I try to put aside as much as I can, but it's still a struggle. Sometimes, I feel like we're just barely keeping our heads above water, but I know that every dollar we save, every small step we take, is helping us move forward. It's not about having a lot—it's about not giving up, and that's something I'm learning to believe in more every day.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Angel Rodriguez: I've been working at the bookstore for about a year now, and it's been a good fit for me. The hours are flexible, which helps me balance school and my other responsibilities. As for benefits, well, I don't get health insurance or paid time off through the job, but the manager is pretty understanding when things get tough. If I'm running late because of school or need to leave early for a family emergency, she usually lets me make it up another day. The best part is the people I work with—they're like a second family. We all have our own struggles, but we support each other. I've learned a lot from them, not just about books, but about life. It's not a perfect job, but it's given me a sense of purpose and a little bit of independence, which means a lot to me.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Angel Rodriguez: My relationships at work are pretty good, honestly. My manager, Ms. Lopez, is someone I really respect. She's been through a lot in her life, just like me, and she always reminds me that it's okay to struggle as long as I keep trying. She's never been harsh with me, even when I've made mistakes, and she's always willing to give me a second chance. As for my coworkers, we all have our own stories, our own reasons for being there. Some of them are students like me, others are older and have been working for years. We don't talk about our personal lives too much, but there's a sense of mutual respect. If someone is having a rough day, we look out for each other. I think that's what makes this place feel like more than just a job—it feels like a place where people care, even if they don't know you well. I'm grateful for that because it's not something I take for granted.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Angel Rodriguez: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is one of the reasons I've been able to keep up with school and my other responsibilities. Most of the time, I work weekends and a few afternoons during the week, but if I need to adjust my hours for an exam or a family obligation, the manager is usually okay with it. There are days when I have to stay late to help close up, and other days when I can leave early if I'm running behind. It's not always perfect, but I've learned to plan ahead and communicate with my manager so we can find a solution that works for both of us. I think that flexibility is what makes this job manageable for someone like me, who's still figuring things out but trying to do the best I can.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Angel Rodriguez: Overall, I feel like I'm in a constant balancing act, trying to make ends meet while still working toward something bigger. It's not easy, and there are days when I feel like I'm barely keeping up, but I also know that I'm not standing still. Every month, I'm learning more about how to manage my money, how to prioritize what really matters, and how to ask for help when I need it. I don't have a lot, but I'm not stuck. I see progress in small ways—like being able to save a little each month, or getting better grades in school, or even just feeling more confident in my decisions. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I'm not giving up. I believe that if I keep working hard, staying focused, and making smart choices, I can build a better future for myself and my family. It's going to take time, but I'm ready for that journey.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation has shaped my daily life and decisions. Talking about my bills and how they fluctuate reminded me of the constant struggle to balance everything—rent, groceries, transportation, and unexpected expenses. It's not just about money; it's about learning to adapt and find ways to make it work, even when things get tight. I used to feel like I was failing because I couldn't afford everything, but now I see it as part of the journey. I've also come to understand that saving, even in small ways, is important for my future. It's not about having a lot—it's about being responsible and making the most of what I have. I'm still learning, but I'm proud of how far I've come and how much I've grown in managing my finances and staying focused on my goals.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Angel Rodriguez: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked at a factory for over ten years, and my mom was a house cleaner for different families. They both worked long hours, often from early morning until late afternoon, and sometimes even into the evening. I remember seeing my mom come home exhausted, her hands sore from scrubbing floors, and my dad would be quiet after his shift, just sitting on the couch with his hat on. They never complained, but I could tell they were tired. They always made sure I had food on the table and a place to sleep, even when they didn't have much themselves. I used to feel guilty for wanting more, for wanting to go to college, because I knew they had given up a lot to give me a chance. But looking back, I realize that their hard work was the foundation that got me here. I didn't know it at the time, but they were building a future for me, even if they couldn't see it themselves. That's why I'm so determined to make something of myself—not just for me, but for them too.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Angel Rodriguez: My dad worked at a factory assembling parts for automotive companies. It was physically demanding work—he stood for long hours on the line, moving heavy components and following strict procedures. His most important duties were making sure the products met quality standards and keeping up with the pace of the production line. My mom worked as a house cleaner, often for multiple families in the same day. She'd clean floors, wash dishes, do laundry, and sometimes even cook meals for the families she worked for. Her most important duties were making sure the homes were spotless and the families were satisfied. Both of them had to be very responsible and reliable, because their jobs depended on showing up on time and doing the work right. I remember seeing how tired they were after work, but they never stopped pushing forward. They gave up a lot of their own time and comfort so that I could have a better life, and that's something I'll never forget.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Angel Rodriguez: My dad worked for a local automotive parts manufacturer, and my mom worked for a cleaning service that contracted out to different families in our neighborhood. The factory was a big place, with long rows of workers assembling parts for cars. It was loud, hot, and sometimes dangerous, but my dad always said it was steady work. He never talked much about the conditions, just about the fact that it paid the bills. My mom's job was more varied—some days she'd clean a single-family home, other days she'd work for a larger household with multiple floors and more chores. She always said she liked the variety, but I could tell it was hard on her body. Both of them worked for businesses that didn't offer much in the way of benefits or job security, but they never stopped showing up. That's what I remember most about their jobs—they were just two people trying to make the best of what they had, so that I could have more than they ever did.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Angel Rodriguez: A few years from now, I hope I'm still working toward my degree, maybe at a four-year university, and that I've found a way to make my education more affordable. I want to be in a place where I can focus on my studies without constantly worrying about money or whether I'll be able to afford the next semester. I also hope I'm living in a place that's a little more stable, maybe even with my own apartment, and that I've managed to save enough to take care of my family when they need me. Most of all, I hope I'm not just surviving, but actually thriving—feeling proud of the work I've done, the obstacles I've overcome, and the person I've become. I want to be the kind of person my sister can look up to, someone who shows her that it's possible to dream bigger than what you see around you. I know it's a long road, but I believe in myself, and I believe in the people who've helped me get this far. I just hope I'm still moving forward, one step at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Angel Rodriguez: What I value the most in my life is the people who have believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself. My family, my teachers, my friends, and even the neighbors who've offered a kind word or a helping hand—they've all been part of the foundation that got me here. I value my education because it's the one thing that can truly change my future, not just for me, but for my sister and my parents too. I also value resilience—the ability to keep going, even when everything feels heavy. I've learned that life isn't about having everything perfect, but about showing up every day and doing your best, even when it's hard. And I value hope, because without it, I wouldn't have the strength to keep fighting for something bigger than myself.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my job at the bookstore has become more than just a way to earn money—it's become a part of my identity and a source of stability in my life. Talking about my financial situation reminded me of how much I've had to balance everything—school, work, family, and my own well-being. It's not easy, but I've learned to be more responsible with my time and money, and that gives me a sense of control. I also realized how important the relationships I've built at work are. My manager and coworkers have been more than just people I work with; they've been a support system that helps me keep going, even when things get tough. I'm grateful for the flexibility of my job, which allows me to manage my schedule while still working toward my goals. It's not perfect, but it's a step in the right direction, and I'm proud of how far I've come.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of self-discovery and gratitude. It reminded me of how far I've come, from growing up in a working-class family in Los Angeles to making the conscious choice to break the cycle through education. I never imagined I'd be sitting here talking about my struggles with asthma, my part-time job at the bookstore, or the support I've received from my family, friends, and mentors. It's humbling to reflect on the people who have believed in me—my teacher Mrs. Alvarez, my roommate Javier, my sister Maria, and even my parents, who never stopped pushing me to be better. This interview has shown me that my story isn't just about the challenges I've faced, but also about the resilience, love, and hope that have carried me through. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm proud of the progress I've made and the person I'm becoming. I know I'm still learning, but I'm ready to keep moving forward, one step at a time.
